article:
Kang Full is a South Korean cartoonist, best known for his work in the webtoon industry. With a career spanning over two decades, Kang has established himself as one of the most prolific and successful webtoon artists in Korea. His works are known for their unique blend of humor, satire, and social commentary, which have resonated with readers of all ages.

# Early life and education

Kang Full was born on March 12, 1974, in Seoul, South Korea. Growing up in a family of modest means, Kang developed a passion for drawing and storytelling from an early age. He spent much of his childhood reading comic books and watching cartoons, which would later influence his own artistic style.

After completing his primary and secondary education, Kang went on to study fine arts at the prestigious Hongik University in Seoul. During his time at university, Kang began to develop his skills as a cartoonist, experimenting with different techniques and styles.

# Career

## Early career

Kang's early career began in the late 1990s, when he started working as a freelance cartoonist for various Korean magazines and newspapers. During this period, he honed his craft, producing a range of humorous strips and illustrations that quickly gained popularity with readers.

In the early 2000s, Kang began to explore the world of webtoons, which were then a relatively new and emerging medium in Korea. He created his first webtoon, "Apartment", which was published on the popular Korean web portal, Naver.

## Career breakthrough

Kang's breakthrough came in 2006 with the publication of his webtoon, "Kong's Quest". The series, which follows the adventures of a group of friends as they navigate the challenges of modern life, quickly gained a large following and established Kang as a major talent in the webtoon industry.

The success of "Kong's Quest" led to Kang being approached by various publishers and media companies, who were eager to adapt his work into other formats, such as television and film.

## Serialized fiction webtoons

In the late 2000s, Kang began to experiment with serialized fiction webtoons, which allowed him to tell more complex and narrative-driven stories. One of his most notable works from this period is "The Doggy Poo", a heartwarming tale about a young boy and his dog.

## Kang's action series: Moving, Bridge, and Hidden

In the 2010s, Kang turned his attention to action-oriented webtoons, with the publication of "Moving", "Bridge", and "Hidden". These series, which combine elements of science fiction, fantasy, and martial arts, have been incredibly popular with readers and have helped to establish Kang as one of the leading creators of action webtoons in Korea.

# Other work

## Children picture books

In addition to his work in webtoons, Kang has also published several children's picture books, which have been well-received by readers and critics alike. His picture books often feature simple, yet engaging storylines and beautiful illustrations that are designed to appeal to young readers.

## The Kang Full Cartoon Alley

In 2019, Kang opened the Kang Full Cartoon Alley, a museum and exhibition space dedicated to his work. Located in Seoul, the Cartoon Alley features a range of exhibits and displays that showcase Kang's art and creative process.

# Working style

## Art Style/Technique and materials

Kang's art style is characterized by its simplicity, clarity, and expressiveness. He often uses a range of techniques, including digital painting and traditional media, to create his illustrations and comics.

Kang is known to be highly prolific and is often working on multiple projects simultaneously. He has stated that he is inspired by a range of sources, including music, film, and literature, and is always looking for new ways to push the boundaries of his art.

## Kang Full Universe

Kang has created a vast and intricate universe that underpins many of his works. This universe, which is populated by a range of characters and storylines, is designed to be highly flexible and adaptable, allowing Kang to experiment with different genres and styles.

# Personal life

Kang is known to be private about his personal life, but has stated that he is married with two children. He is an avid reader and enjoys listening to music in his free time.

2023 Swiss Open (badminton)

The 2023 Swiss Open was a badminton tournament which took place at the St. Jakobshalle in Basel, Switzerland, from March 21 to March 26, 2023. It had a total purse of $210,000.

Tournament

### Venue

The St. Jakobshalle, a multi-purpose indoor arena in Basel, Switzerland, played host to the 2023 Swiss Open. The venue, which has a seating capacity of 9,000 spectators, has hosted numerous sporting events, including badminton tournaments, in the past.

article:
2023 Zim Afro T10

The 2023 Zim Afro T10 is a professional T10 cricket league that took place in Zimbabwe from March 15 to March 26, 2023. The tournament featured six teams, including five from Zimbabwe and one from South Africa. The league was sanctioned by the Zimbabwe Cricket Board and was played at the Harare Sports Club in Harare, Zimbabwe.

#Background

The 2023 Zim Afro T10 was the first edition of the tournament, which was established to promote cricket in Zimbabwe and provide a platform for local players to showcase their skills. The tournament was also seen as an opportunity to strengthen cricketing ties between Zimbabwe and South Africa. The league was played in a round-robin format, with each team playing five matches in the league stage. The top four teams qualified for the play-offs, which consisted of two semi-finals and a final.

#Teams

The six teams that participated in the 2023 Zim Afro T10 were:

* Eastern Cheetahs
* Lions of Harare
* Mid West Rhinos
* Mountaineers
* Southern Rocks
* Western Warriors (South Africa)

#Squads

Each team had a squad of 15 players, including two overseas players. The squads were announced on February 20, 2023.

* Eastern Cheetahs: Chamu Chibhabha (c), Tinashe Kamunhukamwe, Tarisai Musakanda, Ryan Burl, Wesley Madhevere, Richmond Mutumbami, Victor Nyauchi, Tendai Chatara, Donald Tiripano, Tapiwa Mufudza, Daniel Jakiel, Innocent Kaia, Kevin Kasuza, Kudakwashe Macheka, and Brendon Mavuta.
* Lions of Harare: Sikandar Raza (c), Hamilton Masakadza, Craig Ervine, Brendan Taylor, Chris Mpofu, Tendai Chatara, Wellington Masakadza, Ryan Burl, Tinashe Kamunhukamwe, Tafadzwa Tsiga, Ernest Masuku, Shepherd Makunura, Ashley Mbabazeka, Vincent Masekesa, and Tapiwa Mufudza.
* Mid West Rhinos: Vusi Sibanda (c), Prince Masvaure, Peter Moor, Malcolm Waller, Solomon Mire, Neville Madziva, Michael Chinouya, Carl Mumba, Rugare Magarira, Brandon Mavuta, Tendai Chisoro, Regis Chakabva, Richard Mutumbami, John Nyumbu, and Kudzai Maunze.
* Mountaineers: Tony Munyonga (c), Tinashe Muchawaya, Roy Kaia, Tafadzwa Tsiga, Clive Chitumba, Kevin Kasuza, Richmond Mutumbami, Natsai Mushangwe, Kudzai Maunze, Tapiwa Mufudza, Innocent Kaia, Victor Nyauchi, Ernest Masuku, Daniel Jakiel, and Tendai Chatara.
* Southern Rocks: Elton Chigumbura (c), Sikandar Raza, Tendai Chisoro, Roy Kaia, Tinashe Muchawaya, Regis Chakabva, Richmond Mutumbami, Tapiwa Mufudza, Tendai Chatara, Rugare Magarira, Brandon Mavuta, Clive Chitumba, Kudzai Maunze, John Nyumbu, and Ernest Masuku.
* Western Warriors (South Africa): Keegan Petersen (c), Janneman Malan, David Bedingham, Zubayr Hamza, George Linde, Aviwe Mgijima, Sisanda Magala, Hardus Viljoen, Dane Piedt, Beuran Hendricks, Nandre Burger, Akhona Mnyaka, Lutho Sipamla, and Rudi Second.

#League stage

The league stage of the tournament began on March 15, 2023, and ended on March 22, 2023. Each team played five matches in the league stage, with the top four teams qualifying for the play-offs.

* March 15, 2023: Eastern Cheetahs vs Lions of Harare - Eastern Cheetahs won by 7 wickets

article:
College GameDay (football TV program)
=====================================

College GameDay is a pre-game television program broadcast by ESPN as a part of the network's college football coverage. The show, which premiered in 1987, is broadcast live from a different location each week, typically on the campus of a school hosting a major college football game. The program features analysis, discussion, and debate about the day's upcoming games, as well as interviews with coaches, players, and other personalities from the world of college football.

Crew/Staff
------------

### Current

The current crew of College GameDay includes:

* Rece Davis: Host
* Kirk Herbstreit: Analyst
* David Pollack: Analyst
* Desmond Howard: Analyst
* Maria Taylor: Reporter
* Jen Lada: Reporter
* Molly McGrath: Reporter
* Tom Rinaldi: Reporter

### Former

Former members of the College GameDay crew include:

* Lee Corso: Analyst (1987-2020)
* Chris Fowler: Host (1990-2014)
* Erin Andrews: Reporter (2004-2012)
* Samantha Ponder: Reporter (2012-2017)
* Jesse Palmer: Analyst (2008-2017)

History
--------

College GameDay premiered on September 5, 1987, as a studio-based program broadcast from ESPN's headquarters in Bristol, Connecticut. The show was created by ESPN executive producer Norby Williamson, who wanted to create a program that would bring the excitement and energy of college football to a national audience.

In 1993, the show began broadcasting live from the site of a major college football game, starting with a matchup between Notre Dame and Michigan. This move helped to establish College GameDay as a major part of the college football landscape, and the show has since become a staple of the sport.

Over the years, College GameDay has broadcast from over 70 different locations, including some of the most iconic stadiums and campuses in college football. article:
Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt (Hessian State Museum Darmstadt) is a museum of art, cultural history, and natural history located in Darmstadt, Germany. The museum was founded in 1820 and has a rich history of collecting and exhibiting various artifacts and artworks.

# History

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt was founded in 1820 by Grand Duke Louis I of Hesse, who was a patron of the arts and sciences. The museum was initially located in the Old Palace in Darmstadt and was known as the "Großherzoglich Hessisches Museum" (Grand Ducal Hessian Museum). The museum's first collection consisted of artworks and artifacts that had been gathered by the Grand Duke during his travels.

In the 19th century, the museum underwent significant expansions, with the addition of new collections and the construction of a new building. In 1877, the museum moved to its current location on Friedensplatz in Darmstadt. The building was designed by architect Alfred Messel and was completed in 1906.

During World War II, the museum suffered significant damage, and many of its collections were lost or destroyed. After the war, the museum underwent a major reconstruction effort, and many of its collections were rebuilt.

# Building

## Location

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt is located on Friedensplatz in the heart of Darmstadt, Germany. The museum is situated in a beautiful park-like setting, surrounded by several other cultural institutions, including the Darmstadt State Theatre and the Central Station.

## Renovations and extensions

In the 1990s, the museum underwent a major renovation effort, which included the restoration of the original building and the addition of new exhibition spaces. The renovation was designed by architect Peter Kulka and was completed in 2001.

In 2014, the museum opened a new wing, which was designed by architect Dieter Quiram. The new wing provides additional exhibition space and features a striking glass façade.

# Collections

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt has a diverse range of collections, including artworks, cultural artifacts, and natural history specimens. The museum's collections include:

* European art from the 14th to the 20th centuries, including works by artists such as Rubens, Rembrandt, and Picasso
* A collection of ancient Greek and Roman art, including sculptures and coins
* A collection of cultural artifacts from around the world, including textiles, jewelry, and musical instruments
* A natural history collection, including specimens of plants, animals, and minerals

# Gallery

The museum's gallery features a range of temporary and permanent exhibitions. Some of the museum's most popular exhibitions include:

* The "Darmstadt Madonna" by Hans Holbein the Younger, a famous painting that is considered one of the museum's greatest treasures
* The "Hessian Crown Jewels," a collection of precious gems and jewelry that belonged to the Grand Dukes of Hesse
* The "Art Nouveau Collection," a collection of artworks and decorative objects from the early 20th century

# Special exhibitions

The museum hosts a range of special exhibitions throughout the year, including exhibitions on art, history, and science. Some recent exhibitions have included:

* "The Art of the Renaissance," an exhibition of artworks from the 15th and 16th centuries
* "The History of Darmstadt," an exhibition on the city's history and culture
* "The Science of Nature," an exhibition on the natural world and the latest scientific discoveries

# Controversies

The museum has been involved in several controversies over the years, including:

* In 2019, the museum was criticized for its handling of a collection of artifacts that had been looted by the Nazis during World War II. The museum eventually agreed to restitute the artifacts to their rightful owners.
* In 2020, the museum was criticized for its decision to exhibit a collection of artworks that had been created by artists who had been involved in the Nazi party. The museum argued that the exhibition was intended to spark a conversation about the role of art in politics.

* List of natural history museums in Germany

# Films

* "The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt" (2019), a documentary film about the museum's history and collections
* "The Darmstadt Madonna" (2020), a film about the museum's famous painting by Hans Holbein the Younger

2022 BWF World Tour Finals

The 2022 BWF World Tour Finals was the fifth edition of the BWF World Tour Finals, which is an annual badminton tournament organized by the Badminton World Federation (BWF). The tournament was held from December 7 to December 11, 2022, in Bangkok, Thailand.

# Tournament

## Venue

The 2022 BWF World Tour Finals was held at the Nimibutr Arena in Bangkok, Thailand. The arena has a seating capacity of 5,000 spectators and has previously hosted several international badminton tournaments.

## Point distribution

The BWF World Tour Finals followed the standard BWF point distribution system. The winner of each match earned points based on the round they reached, with the champion earning the most points.

## Prize money

The total prize money for the 2022 BWF World Tour Finals was $1,500,000. The prize money was distributed among the winners and runners-up in each category.

# Tie-breaking criteria

In the event of a tie in points, the BWF used the following tie-breaking criteria:

1. Number of wins
2. Head-to-head results
3. Game difference
4. Point difference

# Representatives

## Eligible players

The top eight players/pairs in each category, based on the BWF World Tour rankings, were eligible to participate in the tournament. However, if a player/pair declined the invitation or was unable to participate, the next highest-ranked player/pair was invited.

## Representatives by nation

A total of 16 nations were represented at the 2022 BWF World Tour Finals. China topped the list with 14 representatives, followed by Japan with 8 representatives.

# Performances by nation

China dominated the tournament, winning three out of five categories. Japan and Indonesia also performed well, winning one category each.

## Group B

## Finals

The semifinals saw Viktor Axelsen defeat Anders Antonsen, while Kento Momota defeated Anthony Sinisuka Ginting. In the final, Axelsen defeated Momota 21-16, 21-18 to win the title.

2024 Indian General Election

The 2024 Indian general election is scheduled to be held in India to elect the members of the 18th Lok Sabha, the lower house of the Indian Parliament. The election will be a crucial test for the incumbent government, led by the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), as well as the opposition parties, including the Indian National Congress (INC) and other regional parties.

Background
----------

### Contemporary Politics and Previous Elections

The 2019 Indian general election saw the BJP-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA) return to power with a majority, winning 303 seats out of 543. The INC-led United Progressive Alliance (UPA) won 91 seats, while other parties and independents won 49 seats. The election was marked by a high voter turnout, with over 67% of eligible voters casting their ballots.

Since the 2019 election, Indian politics has been dominated by issues such as the COVID-19 pandemic, economic slowdown, and social unrest. The BJP government has faced criticism for its handling of these issues, while the opposition parties have struggled to present a united front.

### Electoral System

The Indian electoral system is based on a single-member plurality system, where the candidate with the most votes in a constituency wins the seat. The Lok Sabha has 543 seats, with each state allocated a number of seats based on its population. The election is overseen by the Election Commission of India (ECI), an independent body responsible for ensuring free and fair elections.

### Planning

The ECI began preparations for the 2024 election in late 2022, with the aim of conducting a smooth and transparent election. The commission has introduced several new measures, including the use of electronic voting machines (EVMs) with paper trail, voter verification through biometric authentication, and a mobile app for voters to track their applications.

Schedule
--------

### Date Summary

The election is scheduled to be held in multiple phases, with the exact dates to be announced by the ECI. The commission has indicated that the election will be held between April and May 2024.

### Seat Summary

The Lok Sabha has 543 seats, with each state allocated a number of seats based on its population. The seat allocation is as follows:

-------------------

The NDA is a coalition of parties led by the BJP. The alliance includes several regional parties, such as the Shiv Sena, Janata Dal (United), and Apna Dal.

### Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance (INDIA)

The INDIA alliance is a coalition of opposition parties led by the INC. The alliance includes several regional parties, such as the Rashtriya Janata Dal, Samajwadi Party, and Bahujan Samaj Party.

### Other Notable Parties and Alliances

Other notable parties and alliances include the Communist Party of India (Marxist), Aam Aadmi Party, and the Trinamool Congress.

Candidates
----------

### National Democratic Alliance

The NDA has announced several candidates for the election, including Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Home Minister Amit Shah, and Defence Minister Rajnath Singh.

### Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance

The INDIA alliance has announced several candidates for the election, including INC president Mallikarjun Kharge, former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, and former Congress president Rahul Gandhi.

Major Election Issues
--------------------

### Unemployment

Unemployment has been a major issue in the election, with the opposition parties criticizing the government's handling of the economy and job creation.

### Ram Mandir Consecration Ceremony and Sectarianism

The Ram Mandir consecration ceremony has been a major issue in the election, with the BJP and its allies promoting the event as a symbol of Hindu nationalism.

### Electoral Bonds

The use of electoral bonds has been a major issue in the election, with the opposition parties criticizing the government for introducing the system, which they claim allows for anonymous donations to political parties.

Party Campaigns
--------------

### Bharatiya Janata Party

The BJP has launched a major campaign for the election, with a focus on the government's achievements and the party's vision for India's future.

### Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance

#### Crowdfunding

The INC has launched a crowdfunding campaign for the election, with a focus on raising funds from small donors.

#### Funding Issues

The INC has faced criticism for its funding issues, with the party struggling to raise funds for the election.

### Communist Party of India (Marxist)

The CPI(M) has launched a campaign for the election, with a focus on the party's vision for a socialist India.

### Rashtriya Janata Dal

The RJD has launched a campaign for the election, with a focus on the party's vision for a more inclusive India.

### Aam Aadmi Party

The AAP has launched a campaign for the election, with a focus on the party's vision for a more transparent and accountable government.

### Shiv Sena

Party Manifestos

### Indian National Congress

The INC has released its manifesto for the election, with a focus on the party's vision for a more inclusive India.

Misinformation
-------------

The election has seen widespread misinformation, with fake news and propaganda spreading on social media.

Surveys and Polls
----------------

### Opinion Polls

Several opinion polls have been conducted for the election, with the BJP and its allies leading in most polls.

### Exit Polls

Exit polls will be conducted after the election, with the results expected to give an indication of the final outcome.

Voting

### Incidents

Several incidents have been reported during the voting process, including violence and allegations of irregularities.

### Voter Turnout

The voter turnout has been high, with over 60% of eligible voters casting their ballots in the first phase of the election.

Results
-------

### By Alliance and Party

The results of the election will be announced after the counting of votes, with the BJP and its allies expected to perform well.

### By Region

The results of the election will vary by region, with the BJP and its allies expected to perform well in the north and west.

### By State or Union Territory

The results of the election will vary by state or union territory, with the BJP and its allies expected to perform well in states such as Uttar Pradesh and Maharashtra.

Aftermath
----------

The aftermath of the election will see the formation of a new government, with the BJP and its allies expected to form the next government.

Reactions
----------

### International

The international community will be watching the election closely, with several countries congratulating India on its democratic process.

2022 Kharkiv Counteroffensive

The 2022 Kharkiv counteroffensive was a military operation launched by the Ukrainian Armed Forces in September 2022, during the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The counteroffensive aimed to retake control of the Kharkiv Oblast, which had been partially occupied by Russian forces since the beginning of the invasion in February 2022. The operation was a significant turning point in the war, as it marked a major shift in momentum in favor of Ukraine and led to the recapture of large areas of territory.

# Background

The Kharkiv Oblast had been a key battleground since the start of the Russian invasion. In February 2022, Russian forces had quickly advanced into the region, capturing several major cities, including Kharkiv, the second-largest city in Ukraine. Russian forces put up fierce resistance, but were ultimately forced to retreat. The battle was seen as a major victory for the Ukrainian military, and marked a turning point in the counteroffensive.

## Second phase (13 September–1 October 2022)

Albert Cordingley

Albert Cordingley was an English cricketer who played for various teams, including Sussex County Cricket Club, during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Born on October 24, 1871, in Lancashire, England, Cordingley developed a passion for cricket from a young age and went on to have a successful professional career spanning over two decades. This article provides an overview of his life, cricketing career, and legacy.

#Early life and development as an amateur cricketer (1871-1893)

Albert Cordingley was born in 1871 in Lancashire, England, to a family of modest means. From a young age, he showed a keen interest in sports, particularly cricket, which was a popular game in the region. Cordingley's early life was marked by a strong passion for the game, and he spent countless hours practicing his skills on local pitches. As an amateur cricketer, he played for various teams in the Lancashire area, honing his skills and developing his technique.

During his teenage years, Cordingley attended local schools, where he excelled in sports, particularly cricket. This experience provided him with valuable exposure and helped him gain recognition as a promising young cricketer.

##Sussex County Cricket Club (1900-1905)

In 1900, Cordingley joined Sussex County Cricket Club, where he spent five successful years. During his tenure with the team, he established himself as one of the top players in the country, scoring numerous centuries and helping the team secure several championships.

##East Grinstead, Sussex (1906-1911)

In 1906, Cordingley joined East Grinstead, a team based in Sussex. During his five-year stint with the team, he continued to excel, scoring several centuries and helping the team secure important victories.

##Pease Pottage, Sussex (1912-1920)

In 1912, Cordingley joined Pease Pottage, a team based in Sussex. During his eight-year tenure with the team, he established himself as one of the top players in the region, scoring numerous centuries and helping the team secure several championships.

#Post-professional playing career (1921-29)

After retiring from professional cricket in 1920, Cordingley continued to be involved in the sport, albeit in a different capacity. He went on to become a successful groundskeeper and coach, sharing his knowledge and expertise with younger players.

Cordingley's experience as a groundskeeper and coach was marked by his attention to detail and dedication to the sport. He worked tirelessly to ensure that pitches were well-maintained and players were well-prepared for matches. His coaching style was characterized by his emphasis on technique and sportsmanship.

In 1929, Pease Pottage Cricket Club, the team Cordingley had played for and coached, was disbanded due to financial difficulties. The demise of the club marked the end of an era, and Cordingley was deeply saddened by the loss.

Cordingley's playing career was marked by several quirks, including his tendency to wear a distinctive pair of gloves while batting. He was also known for his unusual batting stance, which often left opponents and spectators alike in awe.

In addition to cricket, Cordingley was also an accomplished player of other sports, including football and rugby. Although he never pursued these sports professionally, he enjoyed playing them in his spare time.

Albert Cordingley passed away on January 10, 1939, at the age of 67. His legacy as a cricketer, groundskeeper, and coach continues to be remembered and celebrated by the cricketing community.

Syria national football team

The Syria national football team represents Syria in international association football and is controlled by the Syrian Arab Federation for Football. The team has been a member of FIFA since 1937 and has been a member of the Asian Football Confederation since 1969.

**History**

### From 1936 to 1969: The beginnings

The Syria national football team was founded in 1936, and in 1937, it became a member of the Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA). The team played its first international match in 1942 against Lebanon, which ended in a 2-1 defeat. In the following years, Syria participated in several regional tournaments, including the Arab Games and the Mediterranean Games.

### 1970s: Successes in Arab competitions

In the 1970s, Syria experienced a period of relative success in Arab competitions. The team won the 1973 Palestine Cup of Nations, defeating Egypt 3-1 in the final. Syria also participated in the 1976 Arab Games, where it finished in third place.

### The years 1980-1996: an improvement in Syrian football

In the 1980s and 1990s, Syrian football experienced significant improvements. The team qualified for the 1984 Asian Cup, where it was eliminated in the group stage. Syria also participated in the 1988 Arab Games, where it finished in second place.

### From 1996 to 2007: Years of hope and disappointment

In the late 1990s and early 2000s, Syria experienced a period of hope and disappointment. The team qualified for the 1996 Asian Cup, where it was eliminated in the group stage. Syria also participated in the 2000 AFC Asian Cup qualification, but failed to qualify for the tournament.

### From 2007 to 2012: Great achievements

In 2007, Syria experienced a significant improvement in its football fortunes. The team qualified for the 2007 AFC Asian Cup, where it reached the quarterfinals, where it lost to Iraq. Syria also participated in the 2010 FIFA World Cup qualification, where it reached the fourth round, where it was eliminated.

### From 2013 to 2016: Withdrawal from positions

In the following years, Syria experienced a decline in its football fortunes. The team failed to qualify for the 2014 FIFA World Cup and the 2015 AFC Asian Cup. Syria also experienced a period of political instability, which had a significant impact on the country's football.

### 2018 World Cup qualifiers: Syria close to great success

In 2017, Syria participated in the 2018 FIFA World Cup qualification. The team reached the final round, where it was eliminated by Australia. The match between Syria and Australia was played in Malaysia, due to the ongoing Syrian Civil War.

#### Syria v Australia

The match between Syria and Australia was played on October 10, 2017, in Malacca, Malaysia. The match ended in a 1-1 draw, with Syria's Omar Al Somah scoring the equalizing goal in the 85th minute. The match was significant, as it marked Syria's first-ever World Cup qualification match.

### 2019 Asian Cup: a missed opportunity

In 2019, Syria participated in the AFC Asian Cup. The team was eliminated in the group stage, after losing to Jordan and Australia. Syria's participation in the tournament was significant, as it marked the country's first major international tournament in several years.

### From 2019 to the present

In 2020, Syria experienced a period of relative stability, which had a positive impact on the country's football. The team participated in the 2022 FIFA World Cup qualification, where it reached the second round, where it was eliminated.

#### 2023 AFC Asian Cup: Syria reach the knockout stage for the first time ever

In 2023, Syria participated in the AFC Asian Cup. The team reached the knockout stage for the first time ever, after defeating Jordan and India in the group stage. Syria's participation in the tournament was significant, as it marked the country's first major international success in several years.

Syria has several stadiums, including the Abbasiyyin Stadium, the Aleppo International Stadium, and the Al-Jalaa Stadium. The Abbasiyyin Stadium is the country's largest stadium, with a capacity of 30,000 spectators.

The rivalry between Syria and Lebanon is one of the most intense in the region. The two teams have a long history of competition, with Syria winning the majority of their matches.

#### Syria vs. Jordan

The rivalry between Syria and Jordan is also significant. The two teams have a long history of competition, with Jordan winning the majority of their matches.

Norway at the 2022 Winter Olympics

The 2022 Winter Olympics, officially known as the XXIV Olympic Winter Games, were held in Beijing, China, from February 4 to 20, 2022. Norway was one of the 91 countries that participated in the Games. The Norwegian Olympic Committee and Confederation of Sports (NIF) was responsible for selecting and preparing the country's team. Norway's participation in the 2022 Winter Olympics marked its 24th appearance at the Winter Games.

#Medalists

Norway won a total of 37 medals, including 16 gold, 8 silver, and 13 bronze, making it the country with the most gold medals at the Games. The Norwegian team's performance was led by its cross-country skiing and biathlon teams, which won 12 gold medals between them.

#Competitors

Norway sent a team of 84 athletes to the 2022 Winter Olympics, consisting of 44 men and 40 women. The team competed in 14 sports, including alpine skiing, biathlon, cross-country skiing, curling, freestyle skiing, Nordic combined, ski jumping, snowboarding, and speed skating.

#Alpine skiing

Norway's alpine skiing team consisted of 10 athletes, including 5 men and 5 women. The team's best performance came in the men's slalom, where Sebastian Foss-Solevåg finished 4th. In the women's giant slalom, Ragnhild Mowinckel finished 5th.

#Biathlon

Norway's biathlon team was one of the country's strongest teams at the Games, winning 5 gold medals. The team's performance was led by Johannes Thingnes Bø, who won 5 gold medals, including individual gold in the men's 20km and men's mass start events. Marte Olsbu Røiseland also won 3 gold medals, including individual gold in the women's 7.5km sprint and women's mass start events.

#Cross-country skiing

Norway's cross-country skiing team was another of the country's strongest teams at the Games, winning 5 gold medals. The team's performance was led by Therese Johaug, who won 3 gold medals, including individual gold in the women's 10km classical and women's 30km freestyle events. Johannes Klæbo also won 2 gold medals, including individual gold in the men's 10km classical and men's team sprint events.

#Curling

##Men's tournament

Norway's men's curling team, led by skip Steffen Walstad, finished 6th in the round-robin standings, missing out on a place in the playoffs.

##Mixed doubles tournament

Norway's mixed doubles curling team, consisting of Kristin Skaslien and Magnus Nedregotten, finished 4th in the round-robin standings, qualifying for the playoffs. The team went on to finish 4th overall, losing to Great Britain in the bronze medal match.

#Freestyle skiing

Norway's freestyle skiing team consisted of 8 athletes, including 4 men and 4 women. The team's best performance came in the men's ski cross, where Thomas Borge Lie finished 5th.

#Nordic combined

Norway's Nordic combined team consisted of 5 athletes, including 4 men and 1 woman. The team's best performance came in the men's individual normal hill/10km, where Jarl Magnus Riiber finished 4th.

#Ski jumping

Norway's ski jumping team consisted of 7 athletes, including 4 men and 3 women. The team's best performance came in the men's individual normal hill, where Marius Lindvik finished 5th.

#Snowboarding

2023 SAFF Championship

The 2023 SAFF Championship, also known as the 2023 South Asian Football Federation Championship, is the 13th edition of the SAFF Championship, the biennial international men's football championship of South Asia organized by the South Asian Football Federation (SAFF). The tournament is scheduled to take place from June 21 to July 4, 2023, in Bengaluru, India.

#Host selection

The hosting rights for the 2023 SAFF Championship were awarded to India by the South Asian Football Federation (SAFF) in December 2022. This will be the third time India is hosting the tournament, having previously hosted it in 1999 and 2011.

#Participating nations

Seven teams from South Asia are participating in the 2023 SAFF Championship:

*  Bangladesh
*  Bhutan
*  India
*  Kuwait (invited guest team)
*  Maldives
*  Nepal
*  Pakistan

##Squads

Each participating team is allowed to register a squad of 23 players, including three goalkeepers.

#Venue

The 2023 SAFF Championship will be held at the Sree Kanteerava Stadium in Bengaluru, India. The stadium has a seating capacity of 25,810 and is expected to host all the matches of the tournament.

#Draw

The draw for the 2023 SAFF Championship was held on May 17, 2023, in Bengaluru, India. The seven participating teams were divided into two groups, with each group consisting of three or four teams. The teams were seeded based on their performance in the previous edition of the tournament.

##Draw result

The draw result is as follows:

Group A:

*  India
*  Kuwait
*  Nepal
*  Pakistan

Group B:

*  Bangladesh
*  Bhutan
*  Maldives

#Officiating

The 2023 SAFF Championship will feature referees and assistant referees from various countries in South Asia. The match officials were appointed by the South Asian Football Federation (SAFF) in consultation with the participating teams.

#Group stage

The group stage of the 2023 SAFF Championship will feature two groups, each consisting of three or four teams. Each team will play the other teams in their group once, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage.

##Group A

Group A consists of India, Kuwait, Nepal, and Pakistan. The matches will be played from June 21 to June 28, 2023.

##Group B

Group B consists of Bangladesh, Bhutan, and Maldives. The matches will be played from June 22 to June 29, 2023.

#Knockout stage

The knockout stage of the 2023 SAFF Championship will feature the top two teams from each group. The teams will compete in a single-elimination format, with the winners advancing to the next round.

##Bracket

The knockout stage bracket is as follows:

##Semi-finals

##Final

The final will be played on July 4, 2023. The winner will be crowned the champion of the 2023 SAFF Championship.

#Statistics

##Goalscorers

The top scorers of the 2023 SAFF Championship will be awarded the Golden Boot award.

##Awards

The following awards will be presented at the end of the tournament:

* Golden Boot: awarded to the top scorer of the tournament

article:
Martin Amis

Martin Amis is a British novelist, essayist, memoirist, and screenwriter. He is known for his dense, complex, and often provocative writing style, which frequently explores themes of politics, history, and personal identity. Throughout his career, Amis has been recognized for his innovative and influential contributions to contemporary literature.

# Early life

Martin Amis was born on August 25, 1949, in Oxford, England, to Kingsley Amis and Hilary Bardwell. His father was a novelist and poet, and his mother was a writer and socialite. Amis's early life was marked by a sense of intellectual and literary curiosity, encouraged by his parents' love of literature and their social circle of writers and artists. He attended several schools in the UK and abroad, including the Bishopsgate School in London and the Bronnenberg House School in Switzerland.

# Early writing

Amis began writing at an early age, and his first published work was a short story in the New Statesman magazine when he was just 17 years old. He went on to attend Exeter College, Oxford, where he studied English Literature and began to develop his writing style. After graduating, Amis worked as a literary critic and a journalist, writing for publications such as The Observer and The New Statesman. His early writing often explored themes of youth culture, politics, and social change.

# Main career

## 1980s and 1990s

Amis's first novel, The Rachel Papers, was published in 1973, but it was his 1981 novel, Money, that brought him widespread critical acclaim. The novel's dark humor and exploration of consumerism and capitalism resonated with readers and established Amis as a major literary talent. Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, Amis continued to publish innovative and influential novels, including London Fields (1989) and Time's Arrow (1991). These works cemented his reputation as a master of complex, lyrical prose and a bold explorer of themes such as politics, history, and personal identity.

## 2000s

In the 2000s, Amis continued to experiment with form and style, publishing novels such as The Information (1995) and Experience (2000), a memoir that explored his relationship with his father, Kingsley Amis. He also published a collection of essays, The War Against Cliché (2001), which showcased his critical thinking and intellectual curiosity. Amis's writing during this period often explored themes of politics, history, and personal identity, and he became known for his provocative and incisive commentary on contemporary issues.

## 2010s and 2020s

In the 2010s and 2020s, Amis continued to publish innovative and influential works, including the novels Lionel Asbo (2012) and The Zone of Interest (2014). He also published a collection of essays, The Second Plane (2008), which explored the impact of 9/11 and the War on Terror on Western society. Amis's writing during this period often explored themes of politics, history, and personal identity, and he became known for his bold and incisive commentary on contemporary issues.

## Other work

### University of Manchester

In 2011, Amis became Professor of Creative Writing at the University of Manchester. He has taught creative writing at several universities, including Manchester and Columbia, and has been a vocal advocate for the importance of literary education.

# Personal life

Amis has been married twice, first to Antonia Phillips and then to Isis Rowe. He has five daughters and lives in Brooklyn, New York.

## Death

On May 22, 2023, Amis passed away at the age of 73.

# Views

## Writing

Amis has been a vocal advocate for the importance of literary education and the role of the writer in society. He has argued that writing is a fundamental human activity that allows us to explore and understand the world around us.

## Nuclear proliferation

Amis has been a vocal critic of nuclear proliferation and has argued that the threat of nuclear war is one of the most pressing issues of our time.

## Geopolitics

Amis has written extensively on geopolitics and has argued that the world is entering a new era of global conflict and instability.

## Electoral politics

Amis has been a vocal critic of electoral politics and has argued that the system is corrupt and ineffective.

## Islam and Islamism

Amis has written extensively on Islam and Islamism and has argued that the threat of Islamist terrorism is one of the most pressing issues of our time.

## Euthanasia

Amis has been a vocal advocate for the right to die and has argued that euthanasia should be legalized.

## Agnosticism

Amis has described himself as an agnostic and has argued that the existence or non-existence of God is unknown and unknowable.

article:
Chris Sharma

Chris Sharma is a professional rock climber, born on April 23, 1981, in Santa Cruz, California. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest climbers of all time, known for his incredible strength, technique, and mental endurance. Sharma has been at the forefront of the sport for over two decades, pushing the limits of what is possible on rock.

# Early life

Chris Sharma grew up in a family of modest means, with his parents encouraging his love for adventure and the outdoors from an early age. He began climbing at the age of 12, after discovering a local climbing gym in his hometown. Sharma quickly became hooked, spending every spare moment climbing and honing his skills. He attended high school in California, but dropped out to pursue a career in climbing.

# Climbing career

## 1996–2002 (to Realization)

Sharma's early climbing career was marked by rapid progress and a string of impressive ascents. In 1996, at the age of 15, he made the first ascent of "Narc" (5.14a) in the Owens River Gorge, California. This route was considered one of the hardest in the country at the time and marked Sharma's arrival as a force to be reckoned with in the climbing world. Over the next few years, Sharma continued to push the limits of what was possible, making the first ascents of routes such as "The Game" (5.14d) and "The Ace" (5.14c).

## 2002–2008 (to Jumbo Love)

In 2002, Sharma made the first ascent of "Realization" (5.15a) in the Verdon Gorge, France. This route was considered one of the most difficult in the world at the time and cemented Sharma's reputation as a world-class climber. Over the next few years, Sharma continued to travel and climb, making the first ascents of routes such as "Es Pontas" (5.15a) in Mallorca, Spain, and "Practice of the Wild" (5.14d) in the Owens River Gorge.

## 2008–2013 (to La Dura Dura)

In 2008, Sharma made the first ascent of "Jumbo Love" (5.15b) in the Clark Mountain Range, California. This route was considered one of the most difficult in the world at the time and marked a new level of achievement for Sharma. Over the next few years, Sharma continued to push the limits of what was possible, making the first ascents of routes such as "Golpe de Estado" (5.15b) in Oliana, Spain, and "La Dura Dura" (5.15b) in Oliana.

## Post 2013

Since 2013, Sharma has continued to climb and explore new locations around the world. He has made the first ascents of routes such as "Stoking the Fire" (5.15a) in Santa Linya, Spain, and "Sleepwalker" (5.14d) in the Red River Gorge, Kentucky.

# Legacy

Chris Sharma's impact on the sport of climbing cannot be overstated. He has inspired a generation of climbers and pushed the limits of what is possible on rock. Sharma's incredible strength, technique, and mental endurance have allowed him to achieve what many thought was impossible, and his legacy will continue to inspire climbers for generations to come.

# Personal life

## Zen

In recent years, Sharma has become increasingly interested in Zen Buddhism and has incorporated meditation and mindfulness into his daily routine. He has stated that his practice has helped him to cultivate a greater sense of calm and focus, both on and off the rock.

Jailer (2023 Tamil film)

Jailer is a 2023 Indian Tamil-language action thriller film written and directed by Nelson Dilipkumar. The film stars Rajinikanth, with Aishwarya Lekshmi, Ramya Krishnan, and Yogi Babu in supporting roles. It marks the fourth collaboration between Rajinikanth and Nelson Dilipkumar, after the success of their previous films.

#Plot

The film revolves around Muthuvel Pandian (Rajinikanth), a retired jailer who is living a peaceful life with his family. However, his life takes a dramatic turn when he is forced to take up his old job once again to oversee the construction of a new prison. As he navigates the complexities of his new role, he discovers a deep-seated conspiracy involving corrupt politicians, businessmen, and police officials. Pandian must use his experience and wit to expose the truth and bring the perpetrators to justice.

#Production

##Development

##Filming

The film was shot on a massive scale, with the director using a combination of practical and visual effects to create the film's elaborate prison sets. The shoot was reportedly challenging, with the cast and crew working long hours in hot and humid conditions.

##Post-production

Post-production work on the film began in February 2023, with the director and his team working on the film's editing, visual effects, and sound design. The film's music was composed by Anirudh Ravichander, with the score reportedly featuring a mix of electronic and orchestral elements.

#Music

The film's soundtrack was composed by Anirudh Ravichander, with lyrics by Vivek and Ku. Karthik. The soundtrack received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising the composer's innovative use of electronic and orchestral elements.

#Marketing

The film's marketing campaign began in March 2023, with the release of a teaser trailer that showcased the film's action-packed sequences and dramatic plot twists. The trailer received widespread attention, with many praising the film's visuals and Rajinikanth's performance. The film's posters and promotional materials were also released in the following weeks, generating widespread buzz and speculation about the film's plot and genre.

Jailer was released theatrically on August 10, 2023, in over 2,500 screens worldwide. The film received a massive opening, with many screens selling out on the first day. The film's opening weekend collection was reportedly over ₹100 crore, making it one of the highest-grossing opening weekends of the year.

##Screenings and statistics

##Distribution

The film was distributed by Red Giant Movies, with the company reportedly acquiring the film's distribution rights for a record-breaking price. The film was also distributed by other companies in different regions, including Lyca Productions in the United Kingdom and Canada.

##Home media

The film's home media rights were acquired by Amazon Prime Video, with the film set to be released on the platform in the coming months. The film's DVD and Blu-ray rights were also acquired by other companies, with the film set to be released on physical media in the coming months.

Vijayasinhji Chhatrasinhji
==========================

Vijayasinhji Chhatrasinhji was a notable figure in Indian history, known for his contributions to the country's struggle for independence and his role in the formation of the Indian National Congress. As a prominent leader, he played a significant part in shaping the nation's future and left a lasting legacy.

Biography
----------

Vijayasinhji Chhatrasinhji was born on April 10, 1893, in the princely state of Rajpipla, which is now part of the state of Gujarat, India. He was the son of Maharaja Chhatrasinhji, the ruler of Rajpipla, and was educated at the prestigious Mayo College in Ajmer, Rajasthan. After completing his education, Vijayasinhji Chhatrasinhji went on to study law at the University of Bombay.

### Early Life and Education

Vijayasinhji Chhatrasinhji's early life was marked by privilege and luxury, as he was the son of a maharaja. However, he was also exposed to the harsh realities of life in colonial India, which had a profound impact on his worldview. His education at Mayo College and the University of Bombay helped shape his thoughts on politics and social issues.

### Entry into Politics

Vijayasinhji Chhatrasinhji's entry into politics was influenced by his father, who was a progressive ruler and a strong advocate for Indian self-rule. In 1915, Vijayasinhji Chhatrasinhji attended the Indian National Congress session in Bombay, where he was inspired by the speeches of prominent leaders such as Mahatma Gandhi and Lala Lajpat Rai. This marked the beginning of his involvement in the Indian independence movement.

### Role in the Indian National Congress

Vijayasinhji Chhatrasinhji played a significant role in the Indian National Congress, serving as a member of the party's working committee and participating in several key events, including the Non-Cooperation Movement and the Quit India Movement. He was also a close associate of Mahatma Gandhi and was influenced by his philosophy of non-violent resistance.

New Ecological and Social People's Union

The New Ecological and Social People's Union (NUPES) is a French electoral alliance formed in 2022, bringing together several left-wing parties, including the Socialist Party (PS), the French Communist Party (PCF), Europe Ecology – The Greens (EELV), the Radical Party of the Left (PRG), and La France Insoumise (LFI). The alliance was created to contest the 2022 French legislative election and to provide a unified left-wing opposition to the presidential majority.

# History

## Formation

The New Ecological and Social People's Union was formed on May 4, 2022, after several weeks of negotiations between the member parties. The alliance was created in response to the poor performance of the left-wing parties in the 2022 French presidential election, where none of the candidates from the PS, PCF, EELV, or LFI made it to the second round. The NUPES aimed to provide a unified left-wing alternative to the presidential majority and to promote a progressive agenda.

## Expansion

In the weeks following its formation, the NUPES expanded to include several other left-wing parties and organizations, such as the Pirate Party, the New Deal, and the Movement of Progressives. The alliance also attracted the support of several prominent left-wing intellectuals and activists.

## 2022 French legislative election

The NUPES contested the 2022 French legislative election, with a total of 566 candidates across the country. The alliance presented a unified platform, emphasizing issues such as social justice, environmental protection, and democratic reform. The NUPES also committed to promoting a more participatory and inclusive form of democracy.

## Electoral results and aftermath

The NUPES performed relatively well in the 2022 French legislative election, winning 131 seats in the National Assembly. However, the alliance fell short of its goal of winning a majority of seats, and the presidential majority retained its control of the legislature. The NUPES's electoral results were seen as a disappointment by some, but the alliance's leaders argued that the results were still a significant improvement over the left-wing parties' performance in previous elections.

## Election of René Pilato

In the aftermath of the legislative election, the NUPES elected René Pilato as its leader in the National Assembly. Pilato, a member of the PS, was seen as a compromise candidate who could unite the different parties within the alliance.

## Quatennens Affair

In September 2022, the NUPES was rocked by the Quatennens affair, in which Adrien Quatennens, a prominent LFI deputy, was accused of domestic violence. Quatennens denied the allegations, but he was eventually expelled from the LFI and suspended from the NUPES.

## Bayou Affair

In October 2022, the NUPES was embroiled in another controversy, known as the Bayou affair. The controversy centered on the NUPES's decision to support a candidate in the overseas department of French Guiana, who was accused of corruption. The affair led to tensions within the NUPES, with some members calling for greater transparency and accountability.

## Tensions with the Communist Party

The NUPES has experienced tensions with the Communist Party (PCF), one of its member parties. The PCF has been critical of the NUPES's decision to support candidates from other parties, and has accused the alliance of being too dominated by the PS.

## Socialist infighting and election of Martine Froger

In November 2022, the Socialist Party (PS) held a national congress, which was marked by infighting and divisions. The congress eventually elected Martine Froger as the party's new leader, who has been seen as a more left-wing and radical alternative to the party's previous leaders.

## Socialist Party suspension

In December 2022, the NUPES suspended the Socialist Party (PS) from its ranks, following a dispute over the party's decision to support a candidate in a local election. The suspension was seen as a significant blow to the NUPES, and has raised questions about the alliance's future.

# Members

* Socialist Party (PS)

* Metropolitan France: 512 candidates

Several dissident candidates from the NUPES's member parties ran against the alliance's official candidates, including several candidates from the PS and the PCF.

# Ideology and platform

The New Ecological and Social People's Union is a left-wing alliance that advocates for a range of progressive policies, including:

# Reactions

The New Ecological and Social People's Union has been met with a range of reactions from across the political spectrum.

## PS majority and social-democratic left

The NUPES has been seen as a significant development by the social-democratic left, which has been seeking to rebuild and reorganize after several years of decline. The alliance has been praised for its commitment to social justice and environmental protection.

## PS minority and opposition

However, not all members of the Socialist Party (PS) have been supportive of the NUPES. Some have criticized the alliance for being too dominated by the PS, and for not doing enough to promote the party's own policies and interests.

## Extra-parliamentary left

The NUPES has also been met with skepticism by some on the extra-parliamentary left, who have criticized the alliance for being too focused on electoral politics and not enough on grassroots activism and social movement-building.

## Presidential majority

The NUPES has been seen as a significant challenge by the presidential majority, which has been seeking to maintain its control of the legislature and to implement its own policies and agenda. The alliance has been criticized by some on the right for being too radical and too divided.
